caseTitle: ANTHONY KWABENA ANYAN v THE HIGH COURT, ACCRA
summary: The Supreme Court of Ghana dismissed an application by Anthony Kwabena Anyan seeking certiorari to quash part of a High Court ruling that he had no interest in property attached during execution proceedings. The applicant, a sub-lessee under Edward Nassar & Co. Ltd, claimed ownership of land wrongfully seized in an interpleader action initiated after Platinum Holdings obtained judgment over a different plot. The High Court had ruled the execution was improper and further held that the applicantâ€™s lease expired when the head lease ended in October 2007, rendering his interest void. The Supreme Court found that the trial judge acted within jurisdiction by assessing the applicant's title, as it was inherently in issue in the interpleader. It emphasized that supervisory jurisdiction under Article 132 of the Constitution applies only to patent errors going to jurisdiction, not mere errors correctable by appeal. The case underscores the limits of certiorari and the proper use of interpleader actions.

rationaleHighlights: The High Court acted within jurisdiction in assessing the applicant's interest because title was inherently in issue in the interpleader.
Supervisory jurisdiction under Article 132 applies only to patent, jurisdictional errors, not mere legal errors.
An interpleader proceeding places the claimant's interest in issue, requiring judicial determination.
Where no patent error exists, the proper remedy is appeal, not certiorari.
The applicant's lease could not exceed the term of the head lease, which expired in 2007.
The court has power under Article 129(4) to amend procedural defects to ensure substantial justice.
Certiorari will not issue where the impugned decision does not amount to a nullity.
The trial judge correctly ruled the execution was wrongful due to misidentification of the property.
